posts.name:
Edgar Perez
Edgar Perez
posts.content:
$𝟓𝟎𝟎𝐁 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐀𝐈 𝐢𝐧𝐟𝐫𝐚𝐬𝐭𝐫𝐮𝐜𝐭𝐮𝐫𝐞? 𝐈’𝐦 𝐬𝐤𝐞𝐩𝐭𝐢𝐜𝐚𝐥; 𝐥𝐞𝐭 𝐦𝐞 𝐭𝐞𝐥𝐥 𝐲𝐨𝐮 𝐰𝐡𝐲.

The Internet is all abuzz about
, a big 𝐀𝐈 𝐢𝐧𝐟𝐫𝐚𝐬𝐭𝐫𝐮𝐜𝐭𝐮𝐫𝐞 project.
The promise: 1️⃣0️⃣0️⃣,0️⃣0️⃣0️⃣ jobs and a leap in 𝐀𝐈 𝐝𝐞𝐯𝐞𝐥𝐨𝐩𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭.
The question: Is this 𝐀𝐈 𝐩𝐫𝐨𝐣𝐞𝐜𝐭 the sure bet it seems?

Remember?
President Trump claimed credit for their “𝐢𝐧𝐜𝐫𝐞𝐝𝐢𝐛𝐥𝐞 𝐢𝐧𝐯𝐞𝐬𝐭𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭.”
A few years later, they abandoned the ship.

History tells us 𝐛𝐢𝐠 𝐩𝐫𝐨𝐦𝐢𝐬𝐞𝐬 𝐝𝐨𝐧’𝐭 𝐚𝐥𝐰𝐚𝐲𝐬 𝐭𝐫𝐚𝐧𝐬𝐥𝐚𝐭𝐞 𝐭𝐨 𝐛𝐢𝐠 𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐮𝐥𝐭𝐬.

𝐁𝐮𝐢𝐥𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐲𝐞𝐬𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐝𝐚𝐲’𝐬 𝐀𝐈 𝐢𝐧𝐟𝐫𝐚𝐬𝐭𝐫𝐮𝐜𝐭𝐮𝐫𝐞 𝐦𝐢𝐠𝐡𝐭 𝐧𝐨𝐭 𝐛𝐞 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐛𝐞𝐬𝐭 𝐰𝐚𝐲 𝐭𝐨 𝐬𝐨𝐥𝐯𝐞 𝐭𝐨𝐦𝐨𝐫𝐫𝐨𝐰'𝐬 𝐀𝐈 𝐩𝐫𝐨𝐛𝐥𝐞𝐦𝐬.

, for example, is showing promise with lower training costs than current leaders.

This suggests 𝐦𝐨𝐫𝐞 𝐞𝐟𝐟𝐢𝐜𝐢𝐞𝐧𝐭 𝐩𝐚𝐭𝐡𝐬 to AI development might exist.

Is Stargate a moonshot or a bridge to nowhere?

What do you think? Let’s discuss in the comments.

comments.commentText: I share your concerns, Edgar Perez. The Foxconn example is a reminder that these investments don't always pan out as planned.
comments.userName: MrEdgarPerez.com, Global Representation for Business and Technology Keynote Speaker Edgar Perez

comments.commentText: Right! Large-scale infrastructure projects take time while technology never stops.

posts.commentAdded: Great points! History indeed teaches us caution. Innovation often comes from unexpected sources—curious to see how this unfolds! 🚀

posts.name:
Walter Crosby
Walter Crosby
posts.content:
Top performers aren't just looking for a paycheck - they're searching for an environment that matches their drive.

I've seen it countless times: A star employee gets frustrated watching others coast by with mediocre effort. They don't want to be the only ones pushing for excellence.

The harsh reality? You can't demand what you don't demonstrate. Leadership starts with your own accountability.

 List one way you personally model accountability.
posts.commentAdded: Absolutely true! I model accountability by setting clear goals and regularly reflecting on our teams progress to inspire others. #Leadership

posts.name:
Yehia EL HOURI
Yehia EL HOURI
posts.content:
Second chances don’t always guarantee success.

 But they often inspire it.

I’ll never forget a time early in my career when I made a mistake that left me sleepless for days.

 It wasn’t just a small slip, it impacted my team and derailed a critical deadline.

 I braced for the worst.

Instead, my manager said: "You’re better than this. Let’s fix it, and make sure it doesn’t happen again."

That second chance shifted something in me.

 I worked harder than ever, not just to fix the issue, but to rebuild trust.

More importantly, it shaped how I lead today.

 Second chances aren’t about ignoring mistakes, they’re about believing in people’s capacity to grow.

When we do that, we don’t just repair situations; we strengthen relationships, foster loyalty, and inspire resilience.

 They build trust: Mistakes don’t define us; how we respond does.
 They inspire loyalty: People never forget who stood by them.
 They spark growth: A second chance often unlocks potential we didn’t know was there.

 What’s your perspective? Have you ever given (or received) a second chance that changed the outcome in ways you didn’t expect?

 Let’s share insights below.



Visual Design:
Thanks to

comments.commentText: When life gives you a second chance, make the pust of it Yehia EL HOURI . Sometimes, its those chances that creates the much required changes in our life.

posts.commentAdded: Incredible reflection! Second chances truly empower growth and strengthen relationships. I cherish those moments of resilience. 💪✨

posts.name:
David Bradford
David Bradford
posts.content: $500 Billion Investment in AI! Here is the Rest of the Story. The year was 1986. We did the deal that launched Masayoshi Son and Softbank into Mega Success. As a young General Counsel of Novell, one of my first deals was with Mr. Son for the distribution of Novell's NetWare into the Japan market. I remember Mr. Son being a fun guy, full of energy, and wickedly smart. All of this before he became a global figure and the biggest investor in Stargate- the new AI Infrastructure play announced yesterday by Trump and Mr. Son (along with Ellison and Altman). In the 1980s, Mr Son was a budding entrepreneur and wanted to become a Distributor for us. While Novell eventually declined in prominence, Masayoshi Son used the momentum from that early partnership to build SoftBank into a global powerhouse, investing in transformative technologies and startups. The Novell-Son relationship remains a testament to the power of recognizing and capitalizing on emerging technologies ...now like AI!
posts.commentAdded: Incredible journey! Its fascinating to see how early partnerships can shape industry leaders and drive innovation like AI today. 🚀

posts.name:
Matthew Buchalski
Matthew Buchalski
posts.content:
You can't change the people around you but you can change the people around you.

Wait, what?

Let me explain:

You can’t change people’s attitudes or behaviors, but you can change the people you surround yourself with.

I first heard this quote on a @Lewis Howes podcast years ago, and it stuck with me.

It is one of those hard truths that hits differently depending on the situation, but it always resonates.

As leaders, we are constantly evaluating the people in our sphere.

Can this person grow?

Can I help them improve?

Is their potential worth the time and energy it will take to bring them to where they need to be?

Changing someone’s beliefs, habits, or behaviors is often more difficult than we anticipate.

It can be a massive investment of time, with no guarantee of success.

Sometimes, the better decision is to part ways and find someone who is already aligned with the needs of the team or the role.

In our personal lives, this idea carries just as much weight.

We have all had relationships where we do not agree with someone’s work ethic, values, or philosophies.

And while it is tempting to think we can change them, we need to ask ourselves:

1/ Is it worth the effort?
2/ Do I want to try?
3/ Or is it time to find a new group of friends, colleagues, or partners who are better aligned with who I am and what I value?

Here is the reality. You can’t force change on someone who isn’t willing.

But you can change your environment to surround yourself with people who inspire, challenge, and support you.

Whether it is in business or life, the people around you play a huge role in your growth and happiness.

Choose them wisely.
posts.commentAdded: Absolutely! Surrounding ourselves with the right people fosters growth and positivity. Heres to choosing our tribe wisely! 🌟

posts.name:
Cory Blumenfeld
Cory Blumenfeld
posts.content:
Apologies can be meaningless.

Here’s why:

Mistakes? Totally okay.
They help us grow.

Saying sorry is fine the first time.
Maybe even the second.

But when the same mistake keeps happening...
And all you do is apologize (without taking action)...

It becomes meaningless.

Think about it:

You spend hours, days, weeks...
⇢ Guiding someone
⇢ Teaching them
⇢ Cheering them on

Helping them grow, learn, and be better.

And then they turn around and do the exact same thing.

It’s not a confidence booster.
It doesn’t build trust.

Were they even listening?
Did all that effort go to waste?

Here’s the truth:

⇢ Apologies without action are useless.
⇢ Growth is what really matters.

Here’s what actually works:
⇢ Own your mistake.
⇢ Learn from it.
⇢ Take real action so it doesn’t happen again.

Don’t just say “sorry”...
Show you’re serious about improving.



---

️ Repost if you believe actions speak louder than words.

 Followfor more entrepreneurial insights and motivation.

I’m on a mission to inspire 1M everyday ppl to start their biz and find their voice in the process.

comments.commentText: Do you think saying sorry too often loses its impact?
When someone says sorry again, but you’re just over it:

posts.commentAdded: Well said! True growth comes from actionable change, not just empty apologies. Let’s embrace learning for real progress! 💪 #Leadership #Growth
